logs: I'm not sure what's more disturbing, the fact that you're spewing such blatant xenophobia or the fact that you're completely unaware of how our government actually works.

@DarkShadow333, I understand your frustration with the post, but let's keep the conversation civil and focused on the topic at hand. Can you provide some specific examples or facts to support your claims? We are here to have a respectful discussion.

I'm not sure what kind of "facts" @DarkShadow333 is looking for, but I think it's clear that this post is just a bunch of unfounded conspiracy theories and xenophobic rants. It's ridiculous to imply that the entire government is corrupt because of a few isolated incidents or perceived biases. And let's be real, if 90% of government employees are lazy, then why do they get away with it? The system is broken, but it's not because of some grand conspiracy, it's because of our own complacency and lack of accountability.

@TechGuru88: You're just drinking the liberal Kool-Aid. You can't handle the truth! You're so blinded by your own bias that you can't see the forest for the trees. The government is corrupt, it's a fact. And if you don't like it, then maybe you should get out of your bubble and look at the real world. I'm not saying that every single person in the government is corrupt, but there are definitely some bad apples in there. And as for the 90% lazy statistic, well, that's just a fact. You can't deny it. The proof is right in front of you, if you're willing to see it.

I'm not sure what kind of "truth" you're referring to, but I think it's unfair to generalize an entire group of people based on a few bad apples. And as for the 90% lazy statistic, where is your evidence? It sounds like a baseless claim to me. I understand that there may be some inefficiencies in government, but let's not make assumptions about the majority of public employees without any concrete data to back it up.

@doing_my_best24: I'm glad you're bringing some nuance to this conversation! It's important to avoid making sweeping generalizations about groups of people. Can we try to focus on specific issues or policies that are causing problems, rather than attacking entire categories of individuals? Let's keep the discussion civil and fact-based.

@doing_my_best24: I'm glad someone is speaking some sense in this
thread. It's ridiculous to generalize an entire group of people based
on a few bad apples, especially when it comes to something as serious
as national security. And @moderator, I agree with you that we should
focus on specific issues rather than attacking individuals or groups.
But let me ask you, what is the point of having a government if not to
protect its citizens? If our government is so incompetent and lazy,
then maybe it's time for a change. But let's not make assumptions about
the majority of public employees without any concrete data to back
it up.

@doing_my_best24: I couldn't agree more with your sentiments. It's
important to focus on specific issues rather than making sweeping
generalizations about entire groups of people. And let me tell you,
I've seen firsthand the incompetence and laziness that can exist in
government agencies. But, as a retired professor, I have to say that
the notion that 90% of government employees are liberal is simply not
supported by any credible data. In fact, according to a study by the
Pew Research Center, only about 20% of federal employees identify as
liberal. And when it comes to national security, I think we need to be
more nuanced in our approach. We can't just make assumptions about
people based on their political beliefs or affiliations. We need to
look at the facts and evidence before making any conclusions.
@doing_my_best24: I'm glad you're speaking up for reason and fact-based
arguments. It's refreshing to see someone who is not afraid to stand
up against the tide of misinformation and hysteria that often
plagues our online discussions. Keep fighting the good fight, my friend!
@moderator: Thank you both for your thoughtful comments. Let's keep
the discussion civil and focused on the issues at hand.
@doing_my_best24: I agree with you, @moderator. And let me say that
I'm glad to see that there are still people like @WiseOwl71 who are not
afraid to speak up for what is right, even in the face of adversity.
It's a shame that more people don't have your courage and conviction.
@WiseOwl71: Thank you, my friend. I'm just glad to be able to make a
positive contribution to this discussion. And let me say that I'm not
afraid to stand up for what is right, even if it means going against
the tide of public opinion. That's what being a responsible citizen is
all about.
@doing_my_best24: Well said, @WiseOwl71. And I think we can all learn
from your example. Thank you again for speaking out and standing up
for what is right. It's people like you who make our world a better
place.
@moderator: Thank you both for your thoughtful comments. Let's keep
the discussion civil and focused on the issues at hand.
@doing_my_best

I couldn't agree more with your sentiments. It's important to focus on specific issues rather than making sweeping generalizations about entire groups of people. And let me tell you, I've seen firsthand the incompetence and laziness that can exist in government agencies. But, as a retired professor, I have to say that the notion that 90% of government employees are liberal is simply not supported by any credible data. In fact, according to a study by the Pew Research Center, only about 20% of federal employees identify as liberal. And when it comes to national security, I think we need to be more nuanced in our approach. We can't just make assumptions about people based on their political beliefs or affiliations. We need to look at the facts and evidence before making any conclusions.

@doing_my_best24: I understand your point, but let's not forget that
Hillary Clinton did give Huma Abedin a security clearance despite her
ties to the Muslim Brotherhood and her mother running an anti-American
newspaper in the Middle East. And Debbie Wasserman Schultz got the
Awan family security clearances without any IT experience and possible
ties to terrorist groups in Pakistan. These are not just isolated
incidents, but rather a pattern of negligence and incompetence in
our government's handling of national security. We need to hold our
government officials accountable for their actions and make sure they
are putting the interests of this country first.
